Jim Remsik, organizer of Madison+ Ruby, joins Sean Devine to talk about the history of the Madison+ Ruby conference and what to expect at the event this weekend.

item.title: On Taking Pictures 121: Not Enough Room For Romance
item.author: Bill Wadman & Jeffery Saddoris
item.description: Do you find yourself looking for signs? Not Stop or Yield, but signs from God, the Universe, or what have you telling you what to do? This week, we talk about signs and how waiting for them can often be an excuse for not taking action. We also talk about memories, specifically how bad humans are at remembering details and how photographs can uncover or even rewrite what you previously believed to be the truth. Plus, fantastic fashion photographer Elizaveta Porodina is our Photographer of the Week.
item.content:encoded:
Do you find yourself looking for signs? Not Stop or Yield, but signs from God, the Universe, or what have you telling you what to do? This week, we talk about signs and how waiting for them can often be an excuse for not taking action. We also talk about memories, specifically how bad humans are at remembering details and how photographs can uncover or even rewrite what you previously believed to be the truth. Plus, fantastic fashion photographer Elizaveta Porodina is our Photographer of the Week.

item.title: Back to Work 183: Remember Who Has the Cannon
item.author: Merlin Mann & Dan Benjamin
item.description:
TOPIC: Wait, what'd I DO?!?
This week, Dan and Merlin talk about anger, misunderstandings, and trying to do the right thing. How bewildering (and emotional) it can be to feel misunderstood—as well as trying to better understand what we may have done wrong.
Emotions are armor-piercing bullets.
item.content:encoded:
TOPIC: Wait, what'd I DO?!?

This week, Dan and Merlin talk about anger, misunderstandings, and trying to do the right thing. How bewildering (and emotional) it can be to feel misunderstood—as well as trying to better understand what we may have done wrong.

Emotions are armor-piercing bullets.

Links for this episode:

David Letterman airs Robin Williams tribute | PopWatch | EW.com

Letterman gave us a glimpse of just how electric Williams’ late night appearances were with a compilation video of his times on the show. The video features some of Williams’ trademark physical, over-the-top comedy, but it also focuses on Williams’ laughter, how he threw his head back and guffawed.

Going Deep With David Rees | National Geographic Channel

Thought Stopping: Why it doesn't work, and what works better.

"Treat Worry like a Heckler, not a Mugger"

All About Change

"What, when I do it, will lead to my long-term well-being and happiness?"

Matthieu Ricard: The habits of happiness | Talk Video | TED.com

What is happiness, and how can we all get some? Biochemist turned Buddhist monk Matthieu Ricard says we can train our minds in habits of well-being, to generate a true sense of serenity and fulfillment.

Showbot

Listener-submitted titles for this episode.

5by5 | The Incomparable #207: I Am Groot

Lane Splitting is Legal in California

This episode was sponsored by our friends at lynda.com (Start learning something new by visiting lynda.com/backtowork and get a free 7-day trial where you can access all of their 2,400+ courses), Harry's (Get a better more affordable shave by using the code COMICS and you'll get $5 off your first purchase), and Varonis DatAnywhere (Try turning your own network shares into a private cloud free for 30 days with an unlimited amount of users and if you visit varonis.com/backtowork you get 5 users free forever).

item.title: DLC 36: Persona Non Golden
item.author: Christian Spicer & Jeff Cannata
item.description:
Jeff and Christian welcome Anthony Carboni from We Have Concerns and Rev3Games to the show to talk all things Gamescom and Gencon. First up is the Microsoft press conference, and everybody has a complaint about how the Rise of the Tomb Raider exsclusivity was handled. Not to mention 3 bundles, the Halo Channel, and no Kinect. For the Sony press conference, the guys are excited about new games including Rime, The Tomorrow Children, and Wild, and SharePlay. Plus, a new game from Bioware, Obsidian gets the Pathfinder license, Sierra making Geometry Wars 3, Kojima and Del Toro combine for P.T. and Silent Hills, and much much more. From the GenCon front, Jeff is excited for Star Wars Imperial Assault, and a whole mess of game announcements.
In the Playlist, Anthony loves Hohokum, Christian loves Swapper, and Jeff loves Diablo 3 for PS4.
During Tabletop Time, Jeff played the final version of the new Plaid Hat game, Dead of Winter, and everyone is buzzing for D&D 5th Edition.
All that, plus YOUR phone calls!

item.title: The Web Ahead 79: Advanced Git with Tobias Günther
item.author: Jen Simmons
item.description: Git is a powerful tool for helping developers collaborate, organize, and code at their best. But like anything powerful, Git can be confusing and overwhelming. Tobias Günther joins Jen Simmons to explain how to get through the pain points. They talk about branching, team workflows, remote servers, submodules, GUI tools, and more.
item.content:encoded:
Git is a powerful tool for helping developers collaborate, organize, and code at their best. But like anything powerful, Git can be confusing and overwhelming. Tobias Günther joins Jen Simmons to explain how to get through the pain points. They talk about branching, team workflows, remote servers, submodules, GUI tools, and more.

item.title: Supercharged 15: Maru the Cat vs. the Dark Side of the Internet
item.author: Adam Dachis
item.description:
This week on Supercharged we’re talking about the horrible parts of the internet and what you can do about them. We’re also answering your questions about using FTP, helping grandparents with computer problems, and tech burnout.
Got a question? Email it to supercharged@toasterdog.com!
item.content:encoded:
This week on Supercharged we’re talking about the horrible parts of the internet and what you can do about them. We’re also answering your questions about using FTP, helping grandparents with computer problems, and tech burnout.

Got a question? Email it to supercharged@toasterdog.com!

Links for this episode:

Taser's new cop-cam takes aim at perps and privacy

Taser, the stun-gun company, created a wearable camera in the form of glasses. It’s not a Google Glass competitor, but a product for the police so they can record incidents. But will this actually help?

You have a right to record the police

Sort of. Under federal law, you’re protected by the first amendment. 38 states allow single-party consent, which means you can record the police so long as you’re doing so passively and not in their way. The remaining 12 states require two-party consent, but 10 of them allow that to be bypassed in the event you’re recording an on-duty police officer doing his or her job. Only Massachusetts and Illinois do not have this provision. If you’re in one of the 48 states that allow it, just make sure you don’t do it in secret.

Twitter says it will improve harassment policies after Zelda Williams quits service

Robin William’s suicide was one of the most poorly-handled issues on the internet. His daughter was harassed to the point where she had to leave Twitter, among other stupid problems.

What Gawker Media Is Doing About Our Rape Gif Problem

Jezebel and other Gawker Media sites were hit with a “rape GIF” problem, meaning commenters left moving images depicting rape in the comments. Gawker eventually had to alter its commenting system to avoid this problem. The moral of the story: the internet is full of bad people.

How Addiction Works, and What You Can Do About It

For many of us, topics like addiction and substance abuse seem far removed, like they affect other people and don't (or will never) concern us—the same way depression, anxiety, or other issues can seem remote to those who don't experience them. But the truth is, addiction is an insidious disease that can creep up on you or very possibly already be hurting someone you know or love, maybe even without you having a clue.

How to Banish Annoying Sites From Your Facebook Feed Forever

There are just some sites you never want to hear from. And most of them end up all over your Facebook feed. However, you can now banish an entire site from your feed forever with this one trick! What happens next will amaze you.

How to Block Annoying Tech Rumors and Movie Spoilers on Your Browser

With the iPad 3 (supposedly) launching soon, movie spoilers hitting the internet before a trailer is released, and the general overabundance of news online, it can be difficult to avoid learning things you don't want (or care) to. Here's how to set up automatic blocks both globally and on specific websites so you can avoid any type of news you want.

This week Supercharged was sponsored by Squarespace and Codeship! Use code SUPERCHARGED for your discounts.

item.title: Isometric 15: The Full Georgia
item.author: Brianna Wu, Georgia Dow, Maddy Myers, and Steve Lubitz
item.description:
This week. we address the Alderaan levels of anguish about Tomb Raider being an Xbox exclusive, challenge the dubious Night Trap Kickstarter, and have a serious adult conversation about gamers and depression. We also affirm your life choices if you play games on easy and find out Georgia's free time is spent on awesome.
Maddy - Ultra Street Fighter IV Georgia - Boggle Bri - The Last of Us and Mass Effect 2 Steve - Wolfenstein: The New Order and Rock Band Blitz
item.content:encoded:

item.title: The Incomparable 207: I Am Groot
item.author: Jason Snell
item.description:
Put in your mix tape and get ready for a climactic dance-off! We're talking "Guardians of the Galaxy," Marvel's latest hit movie and a real departure in so many ways. What makes the movie work? What are its flaws? We break it all down.
With panelists Serenity Caldwell, David J. Loehr, Monty Ashley, and Tony Sindelar.
item.content:encoded:

With panelists Serenity Caldwell, David J. Loehr, Monty Ashley, and Tony Sindelar.
item.itunes:keywords: books, movies, tv, comics, sci-fi, geek

item.title: Grit 53: Under The Desk On Phone Calls
item.author: Dan Benjamin
item.description: With the official name change from Quit to Grit, Dan is joined by Haddie Cooke to talk about negotiations, interviews, open offices, and more!
item.content:encoded:
With the official name change from Quit to Grit, Dan is joined by Haddie Cooke to talk about negotiations, interviews, open offices, and more!

Links for this episode:

Open Plan Offices Makes Employees Less Productive

Open-plan offices may make some kinds of collaboration easier, but are they more conducive to productivity? What’s the most irritating workplace distraction? And are those state-of-the-art workstations actually more comfortable?

5by5 | Back to Work #87: Nothing to Declare But My Coconuts

This week, Dan and Merlin begin a conversation on what researchers and educators are learning about why students of all ages do or don't succeed. Yes, it's about intelligence and other cognitive skills, but it's also about tenacity, courage, self-restraint, and resolve.

Grit (personality trait) - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Grit in psychology is a positive, non-cognitive trait based on an individual’s passion for a particular long-term goal or endstate coupled with a powerful motivation to achieve their respective objective.

And then everyone gets sent to detention.

item.title: Mikes On Mics 133: Making a Living on Creativity with Paul Jarvis
item.author: Michael Schechter & Mike Vardy
item.description:
This week Paul Jarvis pops by to talk with Vardy about how he treats time, his choice of writing tools, and how he is able to make progress on all of the projects he has going on without a to-do list of any sort. (I know, right?!)
P.S. Big congratulations to The Schechter Family, who welcomed Sophie Jules Schechter to the world on August 11th.

Twitter vows to “improve our policies” after Robin Williams’ daughter is bullied off the network - The Washington Post

Internet trolls bullied Robin Williams' daughter off of Twitter and Instagram just days after her father's death. A handful of Twitter users sent Zelda Williams messages on Twitter that blamed her for Robin Williams' suicide by hanging, as well as pictures of the comedian altered to show bruises around his neck.

item.title: Comics, Assembled! 5: He's Invulnerable and He Can Read Minds!
item.author: Brian Ward & Thom Zahler
item.description: Thom and Brian discuss the new Aquaman movie and then take some time to remember Robin Williams, spinning them off into a discussion about the role of Twitter and social media and the challenges of avoiding being pigeonholed. The boys welcome their first sponsor. Plus… lo, there shall come a contest! Tweet, retweet or otherwise mention @comicsalliance on Twitter and be entered to win a commission from Thom!
item.content:encoded:
Thom and Brian discuss the new Aquaman movie and then take some time to remember Robin Williams, spinning them off into a discussion about the role of Twitter and social media and the challenges of avoiding being pigeonholed. The boys welcome their first sponsor. Plus… lo, there shall come a contest! Tweet, retweet or otherwise mention @comicsalliance on Twitter and be entered to win a commission from Thom!

Links for this episode:

Wacom Cintiq Companion

Try to get one of these without Thom's drool on it. It's a portable Cintiq based on a Microsoft Surface.

From the Wacom website: "The Cintiq Companion combines the immersive, on-screen creative experience of a Cintiq creative pen display with the mobility of a high-performance Windows 8 creative tablet - giving you the power to produce professional results from anywhere."

2014 Baltimore Yearbook featuring Grendel

Thom's designed the Baltimore Yearbook for the third year, this time featuring Matt Wagner's Grendel.

Power Morphicon 4

The huge Power Rangers convention in Pasadena, California where you can meet Brian Ward… and lots of actors from the show, too.

Aquaman: Mercy Reef pilot

Years ago, self-assured dive shop owner Arthur "A.C." Curry lost his mother in the mysterious Bermuda Triangle, and now he is honing his amazing aquatic abilities under the tutelage of a cryptic lighthouse keeper. A.C. knows that he must risk everything to protect the world's vast oceans, even if it brings him into conflict with alluring Navy pilot Rachel Torres. As he trains with his haunted mentor and relies on his close confidant Eva, A.C. grows to embrace an even bigger mission: an ominous, invisible war between the world A.C. inhabits and the one that bore him. This grounded, contemporary reinterpretation of DC Comics' Aquaman mythology comes from the acclaimed writing/producing team of Alfred Gough and Miles Millar (Smallville).

Doug Hills' Manga Studio Tutorials

Doug Hills is doing a fantastic job detailing the functions and abilities of Manga Studio. Check it out. And follow Doug on Twitter at @dnhills

The Aquaman Shrine

Curated by Rob Kelly, the world's foremost expert on Aquaman (and fellow Kubert School classmate of Thom) this is a loving look at the King of the Seven Seas.

The Inhumans by Paul Jenkins

The Inhumans are one of Marvel's most enduring oddities. A race of genetic freaks living secluded in their island kingdom of Attilan, their mutations are self-endowed; as a coming of age ritual, each Inhuman exposes themself to the Terrigen Mists, a strange substance that imparts unearthly powers...some extraordinary, some monstrous. But now Attilan is under attack from without and within. Can the Royal Family, led by the mute Black Bolt, repel the foreign invaders who assail their outer defense, as well as the internal threat of Black Bolt's insane brother, Maximus the Mad? Paul Jenkins and Jae Lee infuse one of Marvel's oldest families with a modern sensibility, including international politics, class struggles and the age-old struggle of growing up. Dark and grimly compelling, it remains one of Marvel Knights' most beloved stories.

With Rocket Raccoon’s success, could Marvel & DC revive funny animal comics?

Interesting article from Robot 6 about Rocket Raccoon and will he spawn a new wave of funny animal comics.

The Fantastic Four Omnibus Vol. 1

What Thom's reading: The first thirty issues of Stan Lee and Jack Kirby's superhero adventure comic. A true classic.

Inventing Iron Man by E. Paul Zehr

What Brian's reading: Tony Stark has been battling bad guys and protecting innocent civilians since he first donned his mechanized armor in the 1963 debut of Iron Man in Marvel Comics. Over the years, Stark’s suit has allowed him to smash through walls, fly through the air like a human jet, control a bewildering array of weaponry by thought alone, and perform an uncountable number of other fantastic feats. The man who showed us all what it would take to become Batman probes whether science—and humankind—is up to the task of inventing a real-life Iron Man.

Mythbusters Episode 86: Superhero Hour

The annotated Mythbusters recap of the episode with the Batmobile grappling hook test.

Comics Assembled on Twitter

Comics Assembled is on Twitter! From now until the next episode posts, tweet, retweet or mention @comicsassembled and be entered to win a 9x12 color commission of one character of your choice from CA host Thom Zahler!

Sponsored by Squarespace (use code ASSEMBLE for a free trial and 10% off).

item.content:encoded:
Jim and Dan talk about Microsoft's new ad campaign for the Surface Pro 3, pitting it agains the MacBook Air. They discuss the changing paradigm of keyboard vs. touch, iPhone 6 rumors, and more.

Links for this episode:

Apple - Remembering Robin Williams

We are deeply saddened by the passing of Robin Williams. He inspired us through his passion, his generosity, and the gift of laughter. He will be greatly missed.

Apple - Diversity - Inclusion inspires innovation.

At Apple, our 98,000 employees share a passion for products that change people’s lives, and from the very earliest days we have known that diversity is critical to our success. We believe deeply that inclusion inspires innovation.
